abstract: Critics and supporters sparred over whether a foreclosure deal helps banks even more than struggling homeowners.
snippet: Critics and supporters sparred over whether a foreclosure deal helps banks even more than struggling homeowners.
lead_paragraph: In February, JPMorgan Chase donated a home to an Iraq war veteran in Bucoda, Wash., and Bank of America waived the $140,000 debt that a Florida man still owed after the sale of his foreclosed home. Over the last year, Wells Fargo has demolished about a dozen houses in Cleveland.

headline.main: Foreclosure Deal Credits Banks for Routine Efforts
headline.print_headline: Foreclosure Deal Credits Banks for Routine Efforts

byline.original: By Shaila Dewan and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

abstract: The French president suggested that banks could make profits by taking out cheap loans from the European Central Bank and investing that money in the region’s government bonds. New data show how popular that trade has become.
snippet: The French president suggested that banks could make profits by taking out cheap loans from the European Central Bank and investing that money in the region’s government bonds. New data show how popular that trade has become.
lead_paragraph: If Nicolas Sarkozy loses France’s presidential election, he may want to set up a hedge fund.

headline.main: Forget ‘Zou Bisou Bisou,’ ‘the Sarkozy Trade’ Is the Hot French Export

abstract: Brian T. Moynihan’s 2011 pay was significantly higher than the $1.9 million payout he received in 2010. But some other executives at Bank of America made more than he did.
snippet: Brian T. Moynihan’s 2011 pay was significantly higher than the $1.9 million payout he received in 2010. But some other executives at Bank of America made more than he did.
lead_paragraph: Brian T. Moynihan, chief executive of Bank of America, earned $8.1 million in 2011, a sharp increase from the $1.9 million payout he received in 2010.

headline.main: Bank of America Chief’s Pay Jumps to $8.1 Million
